_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES

Occidental Permian Ltd. has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training, reputable contractors, and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the NGL transloading and storage system. 



STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

Occidental Permian Ltd. covered process is the equipment and piping associated with the NGL transloading and storage system located at 565 Gusher Road in Levelland, TX.  The regulated substances is pentane. The main operation is described below: 

NGLs are received through a truck unloading rack into bullet style storage tanks. Pumps are used to push the NGLs out of the storage tanks and into railcars. No reactions or conversion are taking place at Occidental Permian Ltd., therefore no process chemistry is in order and does not need to be accounted for.

The maximum intended inventory for this facility is approximately 2,300,000 pounds of pentane.  





HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary

Scenario Description: One worst-case analysis has been defined for the covered process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment report, which is included as part of the RMP documentation.  

Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary

Scenario Description: One alternative case release scenario was modeled.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment, which is included as part of the RMP documentation.  



RISK CONSIDERATIONS

Although the storage and use of pentane has inherent potential risks and the worst-case release scenario can potentially reach the community, Occidental Permian Ltd. has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to ma

ke the worst-case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.

In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a release of a regulated substance:

?    The system has alarms.

?    The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.

?    Detection is in place to notify individuals if a leak occurs.

        The system has a firewater protection program.

 



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

As part of the implementation of this Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Occidental Permian Ltd.to manage process safety issues associated with the use of pentane and iso-butane.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed.  The Prevention Program 3 elements include:

?    Process Safety Information

?    Process Hazard Analysis

?    Operating Procedures

?    Training

?    Mechanical Integrity

?    Management of Change

?    Pre-Startup Safety Review

?    Compliance Audits

?    Incident Investigation

?    Employee Participation

?    Hot Work Permit

?    Contractors



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

There have been no accidental releases within the last five years.
